data.name: Part One - Creating Tattoos
entries: Big and small, simple or intricate, tattoos can be an excellent way to develop a character's personality. Whether you want to give the mercenary your players are talking to an air of mystery, or really delve into your rogue's tragic backstory, there are as many reasons to give a character a tattoo as there are for a person to choose one themselves. On the following pages, you will find roll tables for the tattoo's design, placement, minor magical properties and, if you choose, more beneficial magical enchantments. You can use these tables to randomly generate tattoos, or choose whatever design, placement and effect you think would best suit the character.

data.name: Giving Your Tattoos Magical Properties
entries: One of the most appealing aspects of a tattoo for an adventurer is the fact that they can be imbued with magical properties. On this page you will find two lists of potential enchantments, minor magical properties and advantageous enchantments. Minor enchantments provide flavour, and can be helpful to the creative adventurer in some situations, but do not provide explicit gameplay bonuses. Advantageous enchantments, on the other hand, give statistical bonuses, similar to common and uncommon wondrous items. If you are designing a player character, they may start the game with a tattoo with a minor magical property, but are unlikely to have an advantageous enchantment at this point in their journey. As a Dungeon Master, you can treat tattoos with enchantments as if they were magical items, giving them as rewards, or requiring players to earn them in some way. For example, a village of halflings may have a master tattooist who will only work with those who have helped the community in some way.

rows: The tattoo glows faintly in the dark
The tattoo is animated, and moves in a semblance of life
The tattoo roams around the body at will
The tattoo changes depending on its owners mood
The tattoo is only visible under moonlight
The tattoo burns like a brand when touched by someone other than its owner
The tattoo only appears when a particular password is spoken
The tattoo refers to some future event, unknown to the tattoos owner
The tattoo becomes more detailed to an observer as they get to know its owner
The tattoo makes an appropriate ambient sound at the owners will
The tattoo changes according to the time of day
The tattoo glitters and shifts as if it were made of gemstones
The tattoo is the clour of dull iron, and rusts if it gets wet
The tattoo repels dirt
The tattoo is shy, and will try to hide from view
The tattoo is bold, and will try to always be on show
The tattoo changes according to the weather
The tattoo orientates itself to point north
The tattoo looks slightly different to everyone who views it
The tattoo grows more complicated to reflect the owner's accomplishments

entries.name: Advantageous Enchantments
entries: Roll a d20 to determine the tattoos enchantment. These enchantments are significant enough to lend visible properties to the tattoos, which can be recognised by those familiar with these sort of enchantmnets. The specific nature of the enchantment can be determined with a DC15 Investigation check, or a DC10 Arcana check. As these enchantments draw their magical power from their owner, a normal creature is limited to two tattoos with significant enchantments. Otherwise, the creature risks adverse side effects such as exhaustion, unintended magical consequences or the magical tattoos beginning to squabble amongst themselves.

intro: Roll a d20 to determine where on the body the tattoo is placed.
rows: Glowing
Twice a day, a touch can activate this tattoo. It illuminates as if the cantrip {@spell light|PHB} has been cast on it
Electrified

Once per day, if another creature touches this tattoo the owner can cast the cantrip {@spell shocking grasp|PHB} against that creature. The owner makes a ranged spell attack against the creature, on a hit the creature takes {@dice 1d8} lightning damage
Fortified
The tattoo grants advantage on CON saving throws
Mighty
The tattoo grants advantage on STR saving throws
Delicate
The tattoo grants advantage on DEX saving throws
Intricate
The tattoo grants advantage on INT saving throws
Ancient
The tattoo grants advantage on WIS saving throws
Distinctive
The tattoo grants advantage on CHA saving throws
Threatening
The tattoo grants +2 to {@skill Intimidation} checks against creatures that can see it
Charming
The tattoo grants +2 to {@skill Persuasion} checks against creatures that can see it
Shadowy
If this tattoo is placed on a hand or an arm, it gives plus +2 to {@skill Sleight of Hand} checks made with that hand
Vibrant

Once per day, this tattoo can be touched by the owner or another creature to heal the owner for 2d4 hit points. Once this affect has been used, the tattoo fades to be almost invisible until the owner completes a long rest
Obscured
The tattoo grants a +2 bonus to {@skill stealth} checks when it is covered by clothing or armour or similarly hidden from view
Wary
The tattoo adds +2 to its owner's passive perception when it is exposed
Weird

Once per day, you can force a creature that can see this tattoo to make a DC 15 WIS saving throw. On a failed save the creature is {@condition frightened} of you for one hour, or until they can no longer see the tattoo
Illuminating
This tattoo grants its owner {@spell darkvision|PHB} for 60ft
Sacred
The tattoo grants +1 to {@skill Religion} checks. Once per day, you may touch this tattoo to another creature to cast the cantrip {@spell Spare the Dying|PHB}.
Wakeful
The owner of this tattoo cannot be magically put to sleep
Pure
This tattoo grants the owner advantage on saving throws against being poisoned, and resistance to poison damage
Lucky
This tattoo grants a +2 bonus to any skill that is being used in a game of chance. Once per day, you may reroll a 1 that you roll on a d20 for an attack roll, ability check or saving throw

data.name: Part Two - Getting Tattooed
entries: Once you've finalised the design, chosen the enchantment and raised the necessary funds, it's time to get tattooed. In order to be tattooed you must find an artist willing to do the work,travel to their studio and spend the time and gold necessary to tattoo the piece. The cost and duration of a tattooing session is dependent on several factors, including the size, shape and complexity of the tattoo, the location of the studio, whether the tattoo is enchanted and your relationship with the artist. Exact figures should be decided by the DM, but the following pages should provide some guidelines for setting values, and inspiration for unique tattoo artists and studios.

entries.name: Duration
entries: Even the smallest tattoos will take at least an hour to complete . The following table assigns tattoos a size based on there location on the body, and suggests the length of time it would take to create a tattoo of this size, however the time taken will also depend on the skill of an artist and the complexity of the design. Enchanting a tattoo will take an additional hour after the completion of the artwork to ensure the magic is effective and permanent.

entries.caption: Optional Caption
rows: Tiny
Behind the Ear, On a Finger
1-2 Hours
Small
Hand, Foot, Ankle, Scalp, Face, The Back of the Neck
2-3 Hours
Medium
Arm, Leg, Lower Back
3-5 Hours
Large
Chest, Upper Back
5-8 Hours

entries: After being tattooed, a creature must wait until the tattoo is completely healed (1d4 days for each hour the tattoo took to be completed) before they can be tattooed again. The creature can begin to gain the benefits of an enchanted tattoo after they complete a long rest, provided the tattoo does not become infected (see the rules for Infection).

entries.name: Cost
entries: Tattoo artists may charge a flat rate for a piece, or by hour of work. The rate of pay will vary from artist to artist, and some may require payment other than gold, or require additional payment or services. The following table provides guideline for pricing based on the complexity of the tattoo.

rows: Basic (Simple Line Art, Black Ink Only, No Shading)
10gp/hr
Simple (Some Shading or Solid Black Sections, Some Detail, Black Ink Only)
15gp/hr
Fine (Some Colour, Shading, Fine Detail)
20gp/hr
Grand (Full Colour, Complicated Designs, Very Fine Detail, Hidden Elements, Realism or Other Specialty Styles)
50gp/hr

entries: Enchanting a tattoo incurs additional cost. In general, bestowing a tattoo with a minor magical property increases its complexity by tier, i.e. a basic tattoo would be considered simple, a simple tattoo fine, and so on. Imbuing a tattoo with an advantageous enchantment will usually double the cost of the work.

entries.name: Infection
entries: When getting a tattoo, there is always a risk of infection. This depends on the cleanliness of the tattoo studio, and how much care is taken over the tattoo when it heals. On completing their first long rest after being tattooed, the tattooed creature must make a constitution saving throw. The DC of this throw is dependant on the conditions under which the tattoo was given, shown in the table below.

rows: Spotless
DC5
Clean
DC7
Average
DC10
Grimy
DC12
Dirty
DC17
Filthy
DC20

entries: On a succesful save, the wound resists infection. On a failed save, the creature takes 2d4 poison damage, and is Poisoned until the wound is fully healed, (1d4 days for each hour the tattoo took to be completed) or until the infection is cured.

data.name: Tattoo Artists
entries: Tattoo artists can be flavourful NPCs, plot hooks, antagonists or anything else you can imagine. The following tables can be used to generate a random tattoo artist and their studio, or as inspiration to help you create your own characters.

entries.name: Studio
entries: A tattoo artists studio is where they work, and can be as much a reflection of themselves as the tattoos they design. Studios are usually located in cities, where large populations provide them with plenty of business, and are traditionally associated with the seedier parts of town, but an artist can set up shop anywhere.

intro: Roll a d6 to determine the studio's cleanliness.
rows: Spotless
Clean
Average
Grimy
Dirty
Filthy

intro: Roll a d10 to determine the studio's location.
rows: In the basement of a tavern with a reputation for wild bar brawls
In the secret backroom of a legitimate business that the artist shares with a forger
On the city docks, directly on the waterfront
In one room of a thousand roomed temple
In an airy studio in a college of the arts
In the kitchen of a small but beautifully decorated cottage
In a caravan parked at a crossroads, by the side of a road
On a barge, permanently moored in a canal
In a ramshackle shed on top of an abandoned building
In an imposing store front in the town square

entries.name: Artists
entries: The person actually doing the tattooing. Artists can vary wildly in age, demeanour and history, but are often figures of mystery or intrigue, even within the communities they call home.

intro: Roll a d20 to determine your tattoo artist's appearance.
rows: An ancient gnome whose glasses have a dozen lenses
An extravagant drow with a love for flair
A soft-spoken human monk with a shaved head
A brick-red tiefling in a dark coat with a hundred pockets
A gruff, older dwarf with a scarred face and only one eye
A halfling who looks far too young to have been properly trained
A nervous, stammering kenku with shaky hands
A half-orc with at least a dozen visible piercings
A half-elf who carries themself like nobility despite their heavily patched clothing
A dragonborn with inkstained scales
A pair of halfling twins who work together in perfect unison
A heavy-set human with six fingers on their left hand
A wood-elf with a nose that has clearly been broken several times
A tiefling who has adorned their horns with delicate gold jewellery
A Tabaxi whose fur is streaked with grey, despite how young they look
An elegant dwarf with an elaborately curled and waxed beard
A human with a deep red birthmark on their face
A half-elf with close cropped hair and extremely simple clothing
A gnome with several gem-adorned rings on each finger
An elf with a bleached, asymmetrical haircut and no eyebrows

intro: Roll a d8 to determine the artist's speciality
rows: Tiny Tattoos
Script and words
Photo-Like Realism
Religious and Holy Images
Intricate, detailed tattoos
Bright, colourful tattoos
Commemorative tattoos
Magical Tattoos

intro: Add a little extra personality to your character by rolling a d20 to determine a quirk of their tattooing.
rows: They hum constantly as they work
They close their eyes as they work, only opening them once they've finished
They work in absolute silence, stoppingcompletely if their subject speaks
They are afraid to tattoo unless they are blind drunk
Their tattoo machine looks as if it was cobbled together from scrap
They refuse monetary payment, they will only work in exchange for secrets
They communicate only in an unexpected language
They chat incessantly about whatever pops into their head
They sign all of their pieces with their initials
They have no patience for anyone who is hesistant or unsure
They won't tattoo anyone until they've gotten to know them over a cup of tea
They will not let anyone see the tattoo until it is done
They stop to look out of the window for inspiration every ten minutes
They take a lock of hair from everyone they tattoo
They flirt constatntly as they work, but never pursue a relationship
They are so heavily tattooed themselves that you can only determine individual designs after lengthy study
They abhor the sight of blood, and so will only work remotely, using mage hand from another room
They love animals, and keep several pets in their studio, all of which are allowed to roam freely about the room
They are an ex-soldier, and will only tattoo that can sufficiently prove their valour
They will give you the tattoo that they think will suit you, regardless of what you asked them for
